awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity: Catalyzing Change in Calculus
awd_abstract_narration:
The Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program (HSI Program) aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education and build capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI program will also generate new knowledge about how to achieve these aims.  This project at Florida International University will advance the aims of the HSI Program by increasing the success of students in calculus.  Leveraging a partnership with Broward College, this project will implement Modeling Practices in Calculus, a student-centered curriculum in which students learn calculus by engaging in the authentic practices of mathematicians.  Such practices include working in teams, looking at problems from different perspectives, and proficiently using terminology and symbols.  Learning assistants who are near peers will facilitate learning in the classroom, enabling students to learn from mistakes, give and receive feedback, and help one another learn.  The project's research design includes longitudinal measures of student success and the tracking of students who transfer from Broward College to Florida International University. The project will directly affect over 15,000 students enrolled at two HSIs, where over 80% of students are from historically-underrepresented groups.

The specific aims of the project include generating new knowledge about the effectiveness of the Modeling Practices Curriculum and how this curriculum fosters learning for highly diverse student populations. Further, it will generate knowledge about faculty adoption practices and institutional change as it establishes an institutional culture to sustain and expand the intervention. The research design includes randomized-control trials as well as multivariate matching methods to establish a strong evidentiary base for the impacts of the Modeling Practices Curriculum and facilitate comparison of student outcomes, both immediate and longitudinal. Over the period of funding, the project will host eight professional development workshops for faculty.  The implementation-tested Modeling Practices Curriculum materials, instructional guides, and research finding will be disseminated broadly, to two-year and four-year institutions with diverse student populations that are seeking to enhance the learning of calculus.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Catalyzing Change in Calculus (C3) Project developed, implemented, and rigorously tested the Modeling Practices in Calculus (MPC) curriculum and pedagogy at Florida International University (FIU). MPC is a student-centric instructional method where students emulate the practices of mathematicians to learn Calculus in an asset-based, faculty-guided active-learning classroom environment. The project devoted significant effort to propagating MPC, both at partner institution Broward College as well as numerous institutions across the nation. 

The Modeling Practices of Calculus impacted over 6,000 Calculus students at FIU throughout the project’s lifetime and continues to be used in the majority of Calculus sections. Sections using MPC realize an overall increase in pass rates of over 17% when compared to before the project launch, creating the opportunity for these students to continue their pursuit of a STEM degree. A critical project highlight was the use of a randomized trial to establish the impact on student learning, elevating the rigor for STEM education research. The trial was conducted over 3 semesters and included 32 sections and a total of 811 students and resulted in an overall effect size of d = 0.774 (with 95% confidence interval: 0.618, 0.930), a medium/large effect size. In other words, if this was a clinical medical trial, the impact of the treatment was large enough to merit stopping the trial due to lack of impact in the control condition (ie lecture should be replaced with MPC). Further, the results were repeatable, as they include a total of 7 different instructors, across 16 total treatment sections, utilizing the curriculum and pedagogy over the 3 semesters. These results were published in Science, a top research journal, earning high attention metrics and reported in over 90 news stories across 86 news outlets. The outcomes have been reported in three additional peer-reviewed publications, one book chapter, and numerous conference and presentations.

The project included significant dissemination and propagation efforts, driven by the student impacts observed at FIU. Since 2019, mathematics faculty from the local area, as well as across the nation, participated in multi-day professional development workshops in order to learn how to implement the MPC materials. Over 132 faculty from 61 institutions have participated in professional development workshops throughout the life of the project. Evidence from the project shows that a large number of faculty have successfully implemented and adapted the MPC instructional materials to their intuitional context, expanding the project’s student impact well beyond the lead institutions.


Last Modified: 11/26/2024
Modified by: Laird H Kramer
